section.title: The Characteristic Polynomial

ol.li: Learn that the eigenvalues of a triangular matrix are the diagonal entries.
Learn some strategies for finding the zeros of a polynomial.
Recipe: compute eigenvalues using the characteristic polynomial.

section.p: In we discussed how to decide whether a given number \lambda is an eigenvalue of a matrix, and if so, how to find all of the associated eigenvectors. In this Section, we will give a method for computing all of the eigenvalues of a matrix. This does not reduce to solving a system of linear equations: indeed, it requires solving a nonlinear equation in one variable, namely, finding the roots of the characteristic polynomial.

statement.p: Let A be an n\times n matrix. The characteristic polynomial of A is the function f(\lambda) = \det(A-\lambda I_n).

section.p: We will see below that the characteristic polynomial is in fact a polynomial. Finding the characterestic polynomial means computing the determinant of the matrix A-\lambda I_n, whose entries contain the unknown \lambda.

statement.p: Find the characteristic polynomial of the matrix A = \mat{5 2; 2 1}.
Find the characteristic polynomial of the matrix A = \mat{0 6 8; \frac 12 0 0; 0 \frac 12 0}.

solution.p:
We compute the determinant by expanding cofactors along the third column:
\begin{split} f(\lambda) = \det(A - \lambda I_3) \amp= \det\mat{-\lambda, 6 8; \frac 12 -\lambda, 0; 0 \frac 12 -\lambda} \\ \amp= 8\left(\frac 14 - 0\cdot-\lambda\right) - \lambda\left(\lambda^2 - 6\cdot\frac 12\right) \\ \amp= -\lambda^3 + 3\lambda + 2. \end{split}

section.p: The point of the characteristic polynomial is that we can use it to compute eigenvalues.

theorem.title: Eigenvalues are roots of the characteristic polynomial

statement.p: Let A be an n\times n matrix, and let f(\lambda) = \det(A-\lambda I_n) be its characteristic polynomial. Then \lambda is an eigenvalue of A if and only if f(\lambda) = 0.

proof.p:
By the , the matrix equation (A-\lambda I_n)x=0 has a nontrivial solution if and only if \det(A-\lambda I_n) = 0. Therefore,
\begin{split} \lambda \text{ is an eigenvalue of } A \amp\iff Ax = \lambda x \text{ has a nontrivial solution} \\ \amp\iff (A-\lambda I_n)x = 0 \text{ has a nontrivial solution} \\ \amp\iff A - \lambda I_n \text{ is not invertible} \\ \amp\iff \det(A - \lambda I_n) = 0 \\ \amp\iff f(\lambda) = 0. \end{split}

statement.p: Find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the matrix A = \mat{5 2; 2 1}.

solution.p:
In the above we computed the characteristic polynomial of A to be f(\lambda) = \lambda^2-6\lambda + 1. We can solve the equation \lambda^2-6\lambda+1=0 using the quadratic formula:
\lambda = \frac{6\pm\sqrt{36-4}}2 = 3\pm 2\sqrt 2.
Therefore, the eigenvalues are 3+2\sqrt 2 and 3-2\sqrt 2.

figure.caption: The red line is the (3-2\sqrt 2)-eigenspace, and the green line is the (3+2\sqrt 2)-eigenspace.

statement.p:
Find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the matrix
A = \mat{0 6 8; \frac 12 0 0; 0 \frac 12 0}.

solution.p:
In the above we computed the characteristic polynomial of A to be f(\lambda) = -\lambda^3+3\lambda+2. We eyeball that f(2) = -8 + 3\cdot 2 + 2 = 0. Thus \lambda-2 divides f(\lambda); to find the other roots, we perform polynomial long division:
\frac{-\lambda^3+3\lambda+2}{\lambda-2} = -\lambda^2-2\lambda-1 = -(\lambda+1)^2.
Therefore,
f(\lambda) = -(\lambda-2)(\lambda+1)^2,
so the only eigenvalues are \lambda = 2,-1.

We compute the 2-eigenspace by solving the homogeneous system (A-2I_3)x=0. We have
A-2I_3 = \mat{-2 6 8; \frac 12 -2 0; 0 \frac 12 -2} \quad\xrightarrow{\text{RREF}}\quad \mat{1 0 -16; 0 1 -4; 0 0 0}.
The parametric form and parametric vector form of the solutions are:
\syseq{x = 16z; y = 4z; z = z} \quad\To\quad \vec{x y z} = z\vec{16 4 1}.
Therefore, the 2-eigenspace is the line
\Span\left\{\vec{16 4 1}\right\}.

We compute the -1-eigenspace by solving the homogeneous system (A+I_3)x=0. We have
A+I_3 = \mat{1 6 8; \frac 12 1 0; 0 \frac 12 1} \quad\xrightarrow{\text{RREF}}\quad \mat{1 0 -4; 0 1 2; 0 0 0}.
The parametric form and parametric vector form of the solutions are:
\syseq{x = 4z; y = -2z; z = z} \quad\To\quad \vec{x y z} = z\vec{4 -2 1}.
Therefore, the -1-eigenspace is the line
\Span\left\{\vec{4 -2 1}\right\}.

paragraphs.title: Form of the characteristic polynomial
paragraphs.p: It is time that we justified the use of the term polynomial. First we need a vocabulary word.

statement.p:
Let A be an n\times n matrix, and let f(\lambda)=\det(A-\lambda I_n) be its characteristic polynomial. Then f(\lambda) is a polynomial of degree n, of the form
f(\lambda) = (-1)^n\lambda^n + (-1)^{n-1}\Tr(A)\lambda^{n-1} + \cdots + \det(A).
In other words, the coefficient of \lambda^{n-1} is \pm\Tr(A), and the constant term is \det(A) (the other coefficients are just numbers without names).

proof.p:
First we notice that
f(0) = \det(A - 0I_n) = \det(A),
so that the constant term is always \det(A).

warning.p:
When n=2, the Theorem tells us all of the coefficients of the characteristic polynomial:
f(\lambda) = \lambda^2 - \Tr(A)\lambda + \det(A).
This is generally the fastest way to compute the characteristic polynomial of a 2\times 2 matrix.

statement.p:
Find the characteristic polynomial of the matrix
A = \mat{5 2; 2 1}.

solution.p:
We have
f(\lambda) = \lambda^2 - \Tr(A)\lambda + \det(A) = \lambda^2 - (5+1)\lambda + (5\cdot 1-2\cdot 2) = \lambda^2 - 6\lambda + 1,
as in the above .

paragraphs.title: Factoring the characteristic polynomial
paragraphs.p: If A is a n\times n matrix, then the above says that the characteristic polynomial f(\lambda) has degree n. When n=2, one can use the quadratic formula to find the roots of f(\lambda). There exist algebraic formulas for the roots of cubic and quartic polynomials, but these are generally too cumbersome to apply by hand. Even worse, it is known that there is no algebraic formula for the roots of a general polynomial of degree at least 5.

In practice, the roots of the characteristic polynomial are found numerically by computer, for instance using Newtons method. That said, there do exist methods for finding roots by hand. For instance, we have the following consequence of the rational root theorem (which we also call the rational root theorem):

fact.title: Rational Root Theorem
fact.p: Suppose that A is an n\times n matrix whose characteristic polynomial f(\lambda) has integer (whole-number) entries. Then all rational roots of its characteristic polynomial are integer divisors of \det(A).

paragraphs.p: For example, if A has integer entries, then its characteristic polynomial has integer coefficients. This gives us one way to find a root by hand, if A has an eigenvalue that is a rational number. Once we have found one root, then we can reduce the degree by polynomial long division.

statement.p: Find the eigenvalues of the matrix A = \mat{7 0 3; -3 2 -3; -3 0 -1}.

solution.p:
We compute the characteristic polynomial by expanding cofactors along the first row:
\begin{split} f(\lambda) = \det(A - \lambda I_3) \amp= \det\mat{7-\lambda, 0 3; -3 2-\lambda, -3; -3 0 -1-\lambda} \\ \amp= (7-\lambda)(2-\lambda)(-1-\lambda) + 3\cdot 3(2-\lambda) \\ \amp= -\lambda^3 + 8\lambda^2 - 14\lambda + 4. \end{split}
The determinant of A is the constant term f(0) = 4; its integer divisors are \pm 1,\pm 2,\pm 4. We check which are roots:
f(1) = -3 \quad f(-1) = 27 \quad f(2) = 0 \quad f(-2) = 72 \quad f(4) = 12 \quad f(-4) = 252.
The only rational root of f(\lambda) is \lambda=2. We divide by \lambda-2 using polynomial long division:
\frac{-\lambda^3 + 8\lambda^2 - 14\lambda + 4}{\lambda-2} = -\lambda^2 + 6\lambda - 2.
We can use the quadratic formula to find the roots of the quotient:
\lambda = \frac{-6 \pm\sqrt{36 - 4\cdot 2}}{-2} = 3\pm\sqrt 7.
We have factored f completely:
f(\lambda) = -(\lambda-2)\bigl(\lambda-(3+\sqrt7)\bigr)\bigl(\lambda-(3-\sqrt7)\bigr).
Therefore, the eigenvalues of A are 2,\,3+\sqrt7,\,3-\sqrt7.

paragraphs.p:
In the above Example, we could have expanded cofactors along the second column to obtain
f(\lambda) = (2-\lambda)\det\mat{7-\lambda, 3; -3 -1-\lambda}.
Since 2-\lambda was the only nonzero entry in its column, this expression already has the 2-\lambda term factored out: the rational root theorem was not needed. The determinant in the above expression is the characteristic polynomial of the matrix \smallmat 73{-3}{-1}, so we can compute it using the trace and determinant:
f(\lambda) = (2-\lambda)\bigl(\lambda^2-(7-1)\lambda+(-7+9)\bigr) = (2-\lambda)(\lambda^2-6\lambda+2).

paragraphs.title: Eigenvalues of a triangular matrix
paragraphs.p: It is easy to compute the determinant of an upper- or lower-triangular matrix; this makes it easy to find its eigenvalues as well.

statement.p: If A is an upper- or lower-triangular matrix, then the eigenvalues of A are its diagonal entries.

proof.p:
Suppose for simplicity that A is a 3\times 3 upper-triangular matrix:
A = \mat{a_{11} a_{12} a_{13}; 0 a_{22} a_{23}; 0 0 a_{33}}.
Its characteristic polynomial is
f(\lambda) = \det(A-\lambda I_3) = \det\mat{a_{11}-\lambda, a_{12} a_{13}; 0 a_{22}-\lambda, a_{23}; 0 0 a_{33}-\lambda}.
This is also an upper-triangular matrix, so the determinant is the product of the diagonal entries:
f(\lambda) = (a_{11}-\lambda)(a_{22}-\lambda)(a_{33}-\lambda).
The zeros of this polynomial are exactly a_{11},\,a_{22},\,a_{33}.

statement.p:
Find the eigenvalues of the matrix
A = \mat{1 7 2 4; 0 1 3 11; 0 0 \pi, 101; 0 0 0 0}.

solution.p: The eigenvalues are the diagonal entries 1,\pi,0. (The eigenvalue 1 occurs twice, but it counts as one eigenvalue; in we will define the notion of multiplicity of an eigenvalue.)
